title: Leon Lai
text:
Leon Lai Ming (born 11 December 1966), is a <a href="Hong%20Kong%20people">Hong Kong</a> actor, film director, businessman and <a href="Cantopop">Cantopop</a> singer. He is one of the "" of Hong Kong. He uses his Chinese name "Li Ming" or "Lai Ming", which literally means "<a href="dawn">dawn</a>".
Early life.
Lai was born in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="China">China</a> as Lai Chit (), initially, but opted for Lai Ming instead. He is of <a href="Hakka">Hakka</a> ancestry. His family was originally from <a href="Mei%20County%2C%20Guangdong">Meixian</a>. His parents divorced when he was four. He migrated with his Indonesian Chinese father, Lai Xinsheng, to <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> . At the age of 15, he attended <a href="Lewisham%20College">Lewisham College</a> in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, but returned to Hong Kong at 18 in 1984.
Career.
Early years.
Lai initially worked as a salesperson for a mobile phone company. After being awarded second-runner-up in the 1986 <a href="New%20Talent%20Singing%20Awards">New Talent Singing Awards</a>, Lai received vocal coaching from Dai Si Zong (). In the same year he signed with <a href="Capital%20Artists">Capital Artists</a>. He did not release any albums for four years. As a result, his teacher, Dai, arranged to have him signed a contract with <a href="PolyGram">Polygram</a>, later known as <a href="Universal%20Music">Universal Music</a>.
Music.
In Polygram, he released his first album "Leon" and subsequent album "Meet in the Rain". His debut album went gold. 
In the early stages of his career, he mainly sang <a href="Cantopop">Cantopop</a> and Mandarin, but due to the influence of producer <a href="Mark%20Lui">Mark Lui</a>, he expanded his repertoire to include popular electronic songs with compelling music videos. In 1990 he won his first <a href="1990%20Jade%20Solid%20Gold%20Top%2010%20Awards">1990 Jade Solid Gold Top 10 Awards</a> and <a href="1990%20RTHK%20Top%2010%20Gold%20Songs%20Awards">1990 RTHK Top 10 Gold Songs Awards</a>. He followed up to win the "Most Popular Male Singer" award in 1993 and 1995 for <a href="TVB">TVB</a> <a href="Jade%20Solid%20Gold">Jade Solid Gold</a>. In 1996, he collaborated with composer-producer <a href="Steve%20Barakatt">Steve Barakatt</a> on his album "Feel". Two years later in 1998, he became the first Hong Kong singer to reach the Top 10 <a href="K-pop">K-pop</a> chart with the song "After Loving You." 
In 2002 he was selected to sing "Charged Up", the <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a> theme song for the <a href="Greater%20China">Greater China</a> region. In 2004, he became the first Hong Kong singer to represent the territory at the first <a href="Asia%20Song%20Festival">Asia Song Festival</a> held in <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>.
Lai was selected to be the ambassador of the 6th <a href="Winter%20Asian%20Games">Winter Asian Games</a> to be held <a href="Changchun">Changchun</a> in 2007. He sang the Games' theme song and took part in the torch relay. He then joined <a href="Michael%20Wong%20%28singer%29">Michael Wong</a> and <a href="Janice%20Vidal">Janice Vidal</a> and held a three-day "Magic Live" charity concert at Star Hall, Hong Kong from November 9th to 11th, 2008.
Lai holds his concert at the Hong Kong Coliseum, titled "Leon Lai Talk & Sing 2021 Concert", from Jul 10, 2021, for 9 shows.
Duets.
Apart from being a solo artist, Lai has collaborated with other artists. Some of his better known collaborations are "Love Until the End" and "A Happy Family" with <a href="Vivian%20Chow">Vivian Chow</a>, "Really Wish to Be Like This Forever" and "It's Still You" with <a href="Priscilla%20Chan%20%28singer%29">Priscilla Chan</a>, "Song of the Star" with <a href="Alan%20Tam">Alan Tam</a>, "Never Give Up" with <a href="Jacky%20Cheung">Jacky Cheung</a>, "Why did I let you go?" with <a href="Janice%20Vidal">Janice Vidal</a>.
Company founder and singer.
In 2004, Lai formed a new record production company, "<a href="A%20Music">A Music</a>", East Asia Record Production Company Limited, with <a href="Peter%20Lam">Peter Lam</a>. The first album produced by the company, "Dawn" was released in September of that year. The album, "Dawn", was released with minimum promotion as Lai went to <a href="Mainland%20China">Mainland China</a> for a movie shoot on the day of the album's release.
In 2005, Lai invited Taiwanese music producer <a href="Jonathan%20Lee%20%28record%20producer%29">Jonathan Lee</a> to produce his new Mandarin album "A Story". However, by doing so he had to give up the opportunity for a lead role in a big budget <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> movie "Gui Si" due to conflicts in his schedules.
He returned to the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Coliseum">Hong Kong Coliseum</a> on 13 April 2007 to perform in his one night only "Leon 4 in Love Concert," where he performed not only his own hits but also hits from the other three heavenly kings. He performed a total of 18 songs, all of which are newly arranged by <a href="Mark%20Lui">Mark Lui</a>. He subsequently released an album titled "4 in Love" on 3 May 2007, comprising 16 of the 18 songs he had performed at the concert.
In 2004, Paciwood co-invested with Esun Group to develop a music record company, East Asia Record Production Limited, with the music label <a href="Amusic">Amusic</a>.
Acting career.
After the New Talent Singing Awards, he had some opportunities to star in a few TV series. On one occasion, he went for the filming of a romantic serials titled, "Fengyun Era", in <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. There was a stark contrast in height between Lai and the popular lead actress who is only 160 cm tall. The actress then demanded that Lai squat while filming so as to make up for the height differences. Lai had to act through all the scenes with the actress while squatting, but he had to endure it as he was not popular at the time. Not long afterwards his new TVB series, "<a href="The%20Breaking%20Point%20%281991%20TV%20series%29">The Breaking Point</a>", turned out to be a resounding success and propelled him to widespread fame in Hong Kong and Taiwan.
In 1996, Lai was nominated for the "Best Actor" award at the 16th <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Film%20Awards">Hong Kong Film Awards</a> for the film "". The following year in 1997, he won the award of "Best Original Song" for the film "<a href="Eighteen%20Springs%20%28film%29">Eighteen Springs</a>" both at the <a href="Golden%20Horse%20Film%20Festival">Golden Horse Film Festival</a> and <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Film%20Awards">Hong Kong Film Awards</a>. He was again nominated for the "Best Actor" and "Best Original Film Song" award for the film "<a href="City%20of%20Glass%20%28film%29">City of Glass</a>" 玻璃之城的in 1999, but he only won the award for the latter, which he shared with <a href="Albert%20Leung">Albert Leung</a> and <a href="Dick%20Lee">Dick Lee</a>.
Lai was considered by <a href="Lee%20Ang">Lee Ang</a> to act as "Li Mu Bai" in the film "<a href="Crouching%20Tiger%2C%20Hidden%20Dragon">Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon</a>", but he had to turn down the offer as he had an advertising contract and live concert about to start, which would not match his shaven head look as was required for the role.
He collaborated with <a href="Cecilia%20Cheung">Cecilia Cheung</a> 張柏芝 in 2001 for the first time in the <a href="Wong%20Jing">Wong Jing</a> directed romantic comedy film, "<a href="Everyday%20Is%20Valentine">Everyday Is Valentine</a>". In the film, Lai played a serial liar.
In 2002, Lai took the spotlight at the <a href="Golden%20Horse%20Awards">Golden Horse Awards</a>, the Chinese-language version of the <a href="Academy%20Awards">Oscars</a> in Taiwan. He won "Best Actor" for "<a href="Three%20%282002%20film%29">Three: Going Home</a>". Lai played a minor role as "Superintendent Yeung Kam Wing" in "<a href="Infernal%20Affairs%20III">Infernal Affairs III</a>" in 2003. In 2004, he starred with <a href="Faye%20Wong">Faye Wong</a> 王菲 in the romantic film "<a href="Leaving%20Me%2C%20Loving%20You">Leaving Me, Loving You</a>", the story of which he co-wrote with <a href="Wilson%20Yip">Wilson Yip</a> and he was also the creative/production controller of the film. However, the movie was a flop as it raked in <a href="Hong%20Kong%20dollar">HK$</a> 10,529,501 at the box office. Still in that same year he was ranked 8th on the <a href="China%20Celebrity%20100">China Celebrity 100</a> list released by the Chinese edition of <a href="Forbes">Forbes</a>.
In 2005 Lai acted as one of the seven warriors in the <a href="Tsui%20Hark">Tsui Hark</a> directed <a href="wuxia">wuxia</a> film, "<a href="Seven%20Swords">Seven Swords</a>". In the same year in the film "<a href="Moonlight%20in%20Tokyo">Moonlight in Tokyo</a>", he played a developmentally challenged Chinese man who pretends to be a Korean <a href="Male%20prostitution">gigolo</a> in Japan. 
In 2006 Lai starred alongside <a href="Fan%20Bingbing">Fan Bingbing</a> and <a href="Rene%20Liu">Rene Liu</a> in a love and horror, thriller film titled "<a href="The%20Matrimony">The Matrimony</a>" where he played a cinematographer "Shen Junchu", the love interest of "Manli" and "Sansan". "JunChu" was pressurised into marrying "Sansan" after the untimely demise of his true love "Manli" in an accident. The film was released on 8 February 2007. 
In 2007, Lai starred alongside <a href="Kelly%20Chen">Kelly Chen</a>, <a href="Donnie%20Yen">Donnie Yen</a> and <a href="Guo%20Xiaodong">Guo Xiaodong</a> in the <a href="Ching%20Siu-tung">Ching Siu-tung</a> film <a href="An%20Empress%20and%20the%20Warriors">An Empress and the Warriors</a>. He acted as a woodland medicine man who has a romantic relationship with a princess. Lai and Kelly Chen sang the theme song, "Fly With Your Dreams" written by <a href="Albert%20Leung">Albert Leung</a> and composed by <a href="Mark%20Lui">Mark Lui</a>.
He underwent training in <a href="Peking%20Opera">Peking Opera</a> for playing the lead role as "Méi Lánfāng" in the biographical film "<a href="Forever%20Enthralled">Forever Enthralled</a>" which was directed by <a href="Chen%20Kaige">Chen Kaige</a>. He directed the music video for the film where he and Zhang Ziyi sang the theme song, "You Understand My Love". For the first time in his career, Lai played the role of a beggar in the <a href="Peter%20Chan">Peter Chan</a> directed film "<a href="Bodyguards%20and%20Assassins">Bodyguards and Assassins</a>". For his success a <a href="wax%20figure">wax figure</a> of Lai was revealed at <a href="Madame%20Tussauds%20Hong%20Kong">Madame Tussauds Hong Kong</a>.
Community.
Apart from being an actor and singer, Lai is actively involved in the <a href="Community%20Chest%20%28Hong%20Kong%20organisation%29">Community Chest</a>. In the 1990s, he began serious charity work when his father was diagnosed with rectal cancer. The doctors said it was incurable. After the surgical operation, his father survived. When the <a href="Cancer%20Research%20Foundation">Cancer Research Foundation</a> and the UN organization approached him for help, he started getting actively involved in charity work.
His first work with <a href="UNICEF">UNICEF</a> was a China <a href="Poliovirus">polio</a> eradication project in 1993. He raised substantial funds accruing from his supporters, fans, and concert ticket sales. In July 1994, he was appointed the International <a href="UNICEF%20Goodwill%20Ambassador">UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador</a>, thus becoming the first Hong Kong citizen to be given this position. Since 1994, he has been involved in various fundraising activities of <a href="The%20Hong%20Kong%20Committee%20for%20UNICEF">The Hong Kong Committee for UNICEF</a> (HKCU). These activities include seven charity concerts, three charity chocolate sales, and charity walkathons. Lai, along with HKCU representatives, visited <a href="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, Gansu of China, and <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> to study the work of UNICEF and to help promote public awareness to help children. In December 1995, he was appointed as "UNICEF Special Representative to Youth" at the New York headquarters recognizing his contributions for the welfare of the children.
Lai has also been elected as one of The Ten Outstanding Young Persons (TOYP) in 1997, giving him a formal recognition of his professional endeavors and commitment to the community. He bought the first donation ticket, numbered 000001, at a "Children's Education Fund Raising Campaign" launch event at <a href="Tsuen%20Wan">Tsuen Wan</a> <a href="PARKnSHOP">PARKnSHOP</a>'s Skyline Superstore in 2001 to encourage people to contribute to a meaningful social cause. The funds raised were donated to the Community Chest.
He was awarded the <a href="Medal%20of%20Honour%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">Medal of Honour</a> (M.H.) on 12 October 2003 by <a href="Tung%20Chee-Hwa">Tung Chee-Hwa</a>, the <a href="Chief%20Executive%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Chief Executive of Hong Kong</a>.
Since his decision not to receive any music award in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>, he has not appeared on the <a href="TVB">TVB</a> <a href="Jade%20Solid%20Gold%20Best%20Ten%20Music%20Awards%20Presentation">Jade Gold Solid Awards</a> ceremony even as a guest, but to secure more funds for charity, he agreed to perform in the ceremony as a guest performer on 8 January 2005. On 13 May the same year, Lai collaborated with <a href="Mark%20Lui">Mark Lui</a> to compose the song "8858". The song was used as the promotional song for the China Children and Teenagers' Fund (CCTF). The title of song means "Help Me (which sounds like 'bang bang wo ba' in Putonghua)" and the number "8858" represents the SMS number people can use to donate the money.
In December 2005, Lai appeared in a <a href="Hong%20Kong%20government">Hong Kong government</a> television advertisement in support of a gradual political reform package tabled by the ruling government rather than <a href="December%202005%20protest%20for%20democracy%20in%20Hong%20Kong">rapid political reform</a>. This was the first time he got himself involved in a politically motivated advertisement.
Personal life.
Lai was once in a relationship with actress <a href="Shu%20Qi">Shu Qi</a> in 1997, but they broke up on a low note in 2004.
In 2008, Lai secretly married model <a href="Gaile%20Lok">Gaile Lok</a> in Las Vegas at the <a href="Wynn%20Hotel">Wynn Hotel</a>, with his manager and assistant acting as witnesses. On 3 October 2012, the couple announced the end of their four-year marriage. Their joint statement stated that there were "different philosophies in life" which caused the divorce.
In 2017, Lai formed a relationship with his label assistant and later sales manager Chan Wing-yee (), who is 19 years his junior and also a divorcee. On 22 April 2018, Chan gave birth to his daughter.
Commercial anthem incident.
In 2000, Lai's song "All Day Love" () got him into trouble with the <a href="Government%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">Chinese authorities</a> for drawing passages from the <a href="Chinese%20National%20Anthem">Chinese National Anthem</a>, <a href="March%20of%20the%20Volunteers">March of the Volunteers</a>. The starting tune was accused of plagiarism from the anthem. Lai was warned against using the song for commercial purposes.

Awards and nominations.
Lai was rewarded for his loyalty to the Hong Kong Government in July 2019 by the award of its second highest honour, the <a href="Silver%20Bauhinia%20Star">Silver Bauhinia Star</a>. The award highlighted particular mention of "his participation in the promotional footage for the Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Annuity Plan in 2018".
